title: Shoppers in China make themselves right at home in department store
text:
Friday, 24 February 2017 | MYT 11:15 AM Shoppers in China make themselves right at home in department store Let’s sleep on it. A shopper takes a nap while another checks his phone at Muji’s flagship store in Shanghai. Photo: Sohu.com. 
BEIJING: Photos of Chinese shoppers eating and napping on a furniture displays in shops have gone viral online, according to a mainland report. 
The photos captured inside Japanese apparel and housewares retailer Muji’s flagship store in China – on Huaihai Lu, Shanghai’s main shopping street – were shared on China’s microblogging platform Weibo on Wednesday. 
I think it’s all right to sit because everyone else is sitting around,” a woman surnamed Jin told the Yangcheng Evening News, adding that she enjoyed sitting and dozing on Muji’s sofas every time she visits the store. 
“Only for shopping experience, please do not take a long rest.” 
Although there is a sign, it’s not placed on this sofa that I’m sitting on,” said another woman, surnamed Wang, who had been reading a magazine on a Muji sofa for half an hour. 
No one will stop me,” she added. 
Sometimes people sleep for a very long time, but there is nothing we can do except to keep reminding them to remind them not to,” the employee said.

“It’s not that bad, when I see children playing and adults chatting and sitting around on Ikea furniture, I think it adds value to the ‘at home’ feeling that the showroom is trying to convey.” 
“The respect the shop gives to its customer has been abused by uncivilised people.” South China Morning Post
